titleStmt.title: A machine-readable version of Middleton, Thomas, d. 1627 : : The nice valour (1647)

publicationStmt.publisher: Thomas Middleton, d. 1627 (1580-1627) Thomas Middleton, d. 1627 (?) The nice valour [in, Comedies and Tragedies Written by Francis Beaumont and Iohn Fletcher ... Never printed before, And now published by the Authours Originall Copies] London Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley [etc.] 1647

sourceDesc.p: Based on the LION transcription of the version in the 1647 Beaumont and Fletcher folio, checked against images of this edition in EEBO. The Oxford Middleton dates the play to 1622.

Play details
The nice valour. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1647. Authorial attribution is questionable . Date first performed: 1615-1616?

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Duke Shamount 1 Gentleman 2 Gentleman 3 Gentleman 4 Gentleman Lapet Lapet's wife Passionate Lord 1 Servant Soldier Cupid More than one character speaking at once 1 Brother 2 Brother Priest. Hunts. Clown 2 Servant Gal. Plain Fellow Base Poultrot Moulbazon Prologue and Epilogue

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Shamount welcome; we have missed thee long,
Though absent but two days: I hope your sports
Answer your time and wishes.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Very nobly sir:
We found game worthy your delight my Lord,
It was so royal.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I have enough to hear of it,
Prithee bestow it upon me in discourse.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: What is this Gentleman Cuz? you are a Courtier,
Therefore know all their insides.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: No farther than the Taffitie goes good Cuz,
For the most part, which is indeed the best part
Of the most general inside: marry thus far
I can with boldness speak this one man's Character,
And upon honour pass it for a true one;
He has that strength of manly merit in him,
That it exceeds his Sovereigns power of gracing;
He is faithfully true to valour, that he hates
The man from Cæsars time, or farther off,
That ever took disgrace unrevenged:
And if he chance to read his abject story,
He tears his memory out, and holds it virtuous,
Not to let shame have so much life amongst us ;
There is not such a curious piece of courage
Amongst man's fellowship, or one so jealous
Of honours loss, or reputations glory:
There is so much perfect, of his growing story.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: It would make one dote on virtue as you tell it.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: I have told it to much loss, believe it Cuz.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: How the Duke graces him? what is he brother?

sp.speaker: 4 Gen.
sp.l: Do you not yet know him? a vain-glorious coxcomb,
As proud as he that fell for it:
Set but aside his valour, no virtue,
Which is indeed, not fit for any Courtier;
And we his fellows are as good as he,
Perhaps as capable of favour too,
For one thing or another, if it were looked into:
Give me a man, were I a Sovereign now,
Has a good stroke at Tennis, and a stiff one,
Can play at Equinoctium with the Line,
As even as the thirteenth of September
When day and night lie in a scale together:
Or may I thrive as I deserve at Billiards;
No otherwise at Chess, or at Primero:
These are the parts required, why not advanced?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Trust me, it was no less than excellent pleasure,
And I am right glad it was thine. How fares our kinsman?
Who can resolve us best?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I can my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: There if I had a pity without bounds,
It might be all bestowed ~~ A man so lost
In the wild ways of passion, that he is sensible
Of naught but what torments him?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: True my Lord,
He runs through all the Passions of mankind,
And shifts them strangely too: one while in love,
And that so violent, that for want of business,
He will court the very Prentice of a Laundress,
Though she have kib'd heels: and in his melancholy again,
He will not brooke an Empress, though thrice fairer
Than ever Maud was; or higher spirited
Than Cleopatra or your English Countess:
Then on a sudden he is so merry again,
Out-laughs a waiting woman, before her first Child:
And turning of a hand, so angry ~~
He has almost beat the Northern fellow blind;
That is for that use only; if that mood hold my Lord,
He had need of a freshman; I will undertake,
He shall bruise three a month.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I pity him dearly:
And let it be your charge, with his kind brother,
To see his moods observed; let every passion
Be fed even to a surfeit, which in time
May breed a loathing: let him have enough
Of every object, that his sense is rapt with;
And being once glutted, then the taste of folly
Will come into his relish.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I shall see
Your charge my Lord most faithfully effected:
And how does noble Shamount

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Never ill man
Until I hear of baseness, then I sicken,
I am the healthfulest man in the Kingdom else.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Be armed then for a fit,
Here comes a fellow
Will make you sick at heart, if baseness do it.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Let me be gone: what is he?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Let me tell you first,
It can be but a qualm, pray stay it out sir,
Come, you have borne more than this.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Borne? never anything
That was injurious.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Ha, I am far from that .

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: He looks as like a man as I have seen one:
What would you speak of him? speak well I prithee,
Even for humanities cause.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: You would have it truth though?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: What else sir? I have no reason to wrong heaven
To favour nature; let her bear her own shame
If she be faulty.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Monstrous faulty there sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I am ill at ease already.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Pray bear up sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I Prithee let me take him down with speed then.
Like a wild object that I would not look upon .

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Then thus: he is one that will endure as much
As can be laid upon him.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: That may be noble:
I am kept too long from his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: O sir,
Take heed of rash repentance, you are too forward
To find out virtue where it never settled:
Take the particulars first of what he endures;
Videlicet Bastinadoes by the great.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Thumps by the dozen, and your kicks by wholesale.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: No more of him.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: The twinges by the nostril he snuffs up ,
And holds it the best remedy for sneezing.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Has been thrice switched from seven o'clock till nine,
Yet with a Cart-Horse stomach fell to break-fast,
Forgetful of his smart.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Nay, the disgrace of it;
There is no smart but that : base things are felt
More by their shames than hurts Sir, I know you not,
But that you live an injury to nature:
I am heartily angry with you.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Pray give your blow or kick, and begone then:
For I never saw you before, and indeed,
Have nothing to say to you, for I know you not.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Why wouldst thou take a blow?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I would not sir,
Unless it were offered me; and if from an enemy ~~
I would be loath to deny it from a stranger.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: What, a blow?
Endure a blow? and shall he live that gives it?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Many a fair year ~~ why not sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Let me wonder!
As full a man to see too, and as perfect ~~
I prithee live not long ~~

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Let me entreat it:
Thou dost not know what wrong thou dost mankind,
To walk so long here; not to die betimes.
Let me advise thee, while thou hast to live here,
Even for man's honour sake, take not a blow more.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: You should advise them not to strike me then sir,
For I will take none I assure you, less then are given.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How fain would I preserve man's form from shame,
And cannot get it done? however sir,
I charge thee live not long.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: This is worse than beating.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Of what profession art thou, tell me sir,
Besides a Taylor? for I will know the truth.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: A Taylor? I am as a good a Gentleman ~~
Can show my arms and all.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How black and blue they are?
Is that your manifestation? upon pain
Of pounding thee to dust, assume not wrongfully,
The name of Gentleman, because I am one,
That must not let thee live.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I have done, I have done sir,
If there be any harm, beshrew the Herald,
I am sure I have not been so long a gentleman,
To make this anger: I have nothing nowhere,
But what I dearly pay for .

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Groom begone;
I never was so heart-sick yet of man.

div1.stage: Enter Lady, the Dukes sister, Lapets wife.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Here comes a cordial Sir from the other sex,
Able to make a dying face look cheerful.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: The blessedness of Ladies ~~

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You are well met sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: The sight of you has put an evil from me,
Whose breath was able to make virtue sicken.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am glad I came so fortunately. What was it sir?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A thing that takes a blow, lives and eats after it,
In very good health; you have not seen the like Madam,
A monster worth your sixpence, lovely worth,
Speak low Sir; by all likely-hoods it is her husband,
That now bestowed a visitation on me. Farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Husband? is it possible that he has a wife?
Would any creature have him? it was some forced match,
If he were not kicked to the Church on the wedding day,
I will never come at Court. Can be no otherwise:
Perhaps he was rich, speak Mistress Lapet was it not so ?

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.l: Nay, that is without all question.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: O ho, he would not want kickers enough then;
If you are wise, I much suspect your honesty;
For wisdom never fastens constantly,
But upon merit: If you incline to fool,
You are alike unfit for his society;
Nay if it were not boldness in the man
That honours you, to advise you, troth his company
Should not be frequent with you.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.l: It is good counsel sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: O I am so careful where I reverence,
So just to goodness, and her precious purity,
I am as equally jealous, and as fearful,
That any undeserved stain might fall
Upon her sanctified whiteness, as of the sin
That comes by wilfulness.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.l: Sir, I love your thoughts,
And honour you for your counsel and your care.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: We are your servants.

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.l: He is but a gentleman of the chamber, he might have kissed me:
Faith, where shall one find less courtesy, than at Court?
Say I have an undeserver to my husband:
That is never the worse for him: well strange lipped men,
It is but a kiss lost, there will more come again.

div1.stage: Enter the Passionate Lord, the Dukes Kinsman, makes a congie or two to nothing.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Look who comes here sir, his love fit is upon him;
I know it, by that set smile, and those conges.
How courteous he is to nothing? which indeed,
Is the next kin to woman; only shadow
The elder Sister of the twain, because it is seen too.
See how it kisses the fore-finger still;
Which is the last edition, and being come
So near the thumb every Cobbler has got it.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: What a ridiculous piece, humanity
Here makes itself?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Nay good give leave a little sir,
You are so precise a manhood ~~

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: It afflicts me
When I behold unseemliness in an Image
So near the Godhead, it is an injury
To glorious Eternity.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Pray use patience sir.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: I do confess it freely precious Lady,
And loves suit is so , the longer it hangs
The worse it is; better cut off sweet Madam;
O that same drawing in your nether lip there,
Foreshows no goodness Lady: make you question of it?
Shame on me but I love you.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Who is it sir,
You are at all this pains for ? may I know her ?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: For thee thou fairest, yet the falsest woman,
That ever broke man's heart-strings.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: How? how is this sir?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: What, the old trick of Ladies? man's apparel,
Will it never be left amongst you? steal from Court in it?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I see the fit grows stronger.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Pray let us talk a little.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I can endure no more.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Good, let us alone a little:
You are so exact a work: love light things somewhat sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: They are all but shames.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: What is it you would say to me sir?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Can you be so forgetful to enquire it Lady?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Yes truly sir.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: The more I admire your flintiness:
What cause have I given you, illustrious Madam,
To play this strange part with me?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Cause enough,
Do but look back sir into your memory,
Your love to other women lewd man,
It has almost killed my heart, you see I am changed with it,
I have lost the fashion of my Sex with grief of it,
When I have seen you courting of a Dowdy;
Compared with me, and kissing your fore-finger
To one of the black-guards Mistresses: would not this
Crack a poor Ladies heart, that believed love,
And waited for the comfort? but it was said sir,
A Lady of my hair cannot want pitying:
The Country is coming up , farewell to you sir.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Whither intend you sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: A long journey sir:
The truth is, I am with child, and go to travel.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: With child? I never got it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I heard you were busy
At the same time sir, and was loath to trouble you.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Why, are not you a whore then, excellent Madam?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: O by no means, it was done sir in the state
Of my belief in you, and that quits me,
It lies upon your falsehood.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Does it so ?
You shall not carry her though sir, she is my contract.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I prithee thou four Elements ill brewed,
Torment none but thyself; away I say
Thou beast of passion, as the drunkard is
The beast of wine; dishonour to thy making,
Thou man in fragments.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Hear me precious Madam.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Kneel for thy wits to heaven.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Lady, I will father it,
Whoever begot it: it is the course of greatness.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How virtue groans at this?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: I will raise the Court, but I will stay your 'slight.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How wretched is that piece?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: He is the Dukes kinsman sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: That cannot take a passion away sir,
Nor cut a fit, but one poor hour shorter,
He must endure as much as the poorest beggar,
That cannot change his money; there is the equality
In our impartial essence:
What is the news now?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Your worthy brother sir, has left his charge,
And come to see you.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O the noblest welcome
That ever came from man, meet thy deservings:
Methinks I have all joys treasure in mine arms now,

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: You are so fortunate in prevention brother,
You always leave the answerer barren sir,
You comprehend in few words so much worth ~~

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: It is all too little for thee: come thou art welcome,
So I include all: take especial knowledge pray,
Of this dear Gentleman, my absolute friend,
That loves a Soldier far above a Mistress,
Thou excellently faithful to them both.
But love to manhood, owns the purer troth.

div1.stage: Enter Shamonts brother a Souldier, and a Lady the Dukes sister.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: There should be in this gallery ~~ o they are here,
Pray sit down; believe me sir I am weary.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: It well becomes a Lady to complain a little
Of what she never feels: your walk was short Madam,
You can be but afraid of weariness;
Which well employs the softness of your Sex,
As for the thing itself, you never came to it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You are wondrously well read in Ladies sir.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Shall I think such a creature as you Madam,
Was ever born to feel pain, but in travel?
There is your full portion,
Besides a little toothache in the breeding,
Which a kind husband too, takes from you Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But where do Ladies sir, find such kind husbands?
Perhaps you have heard
The Rheumatic story of some loving Chandler now,
Or some such melting fellow, that you talk
So prodigal of men's kindness: I confess sir,
Many of those wives are happy, their ambition
Does reach no higher, than to love and ignorance,
Which makes an excellent husband, and a fond one:
Now sir, your great ones aim at height, and cunning,
And so are oft deceived, yet they must venture it;
For it is a Ladies contumely sir,
To have a Lord an Ignorant; then the worlds voice
Will deem her for a wanton ere she taste of it:
But to deceive a wise man, to whose circumspection,
The world resigns itself with all his envy;
It is less dishonour to us than to fall,
Because his believed wisdom keeps out all.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Would I were the man Lady, that should venture
His wisdom to your goodness.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: You might fail
In the return, as many men have done sir:
I dare not justify what is to come of me,
Because I know it not, though I hope virtuously;
Marry what is past or present, I durst put
Into a good man's hand. Which if he take
Upon my word for good, it shall not cozen him.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: No , nor hereafter?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: It may hap so too sir:
A woman's goodness, when she is a wife,
Lies much upon a man's desert, believe it sir,
If there be fault in her , I will pawn my life on it,
It is first in him, if she were ever good,
That makes one; knowing not a husband yet,
Or what he may be, I promise no more virtues,
Than I may well perform, for that were cozenage.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Happy were he that had you with all fears,
That is my opinion, Lady.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: What say you now sir?
Dare you give confidence to your own eyes?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Not yet I dare not.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No ?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Scarce yet, or yet:
Although I see it is he. Why can a thing,
That is but myself divided be so false?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Nay do but mark how the chair plays his part too:
How amorously it is bent.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Hell take thy bad thoughts,
For they are strange ones. Never take delight
To make a torment worse. Look on them heaven,
For that is a brother: send me a fair enemy,
And take him; for a fouler fiend there breathes not:
I will not sin, to think there is ill in her ,
But what is of his producing.
Yet goodness, whose enclosure is but flesh,
Holds out oft times but sorrily. But as black sir,
As ever kindred was: I hate mine own blood,
Because it is so near thine. Live without honesty,
And mayst thou die with an unmoistened eye,
And no tear follow thee.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: You are wondrous merry sir; I would your Brother heard you.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: O my sister
I would not out of the way, let fall my words Lady,
For the precisest humour.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Yea, so close.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: They are merry, that is the worst you can report on them;
They are neither dangerous, nor immodest.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: So sir,
Shall I believe you, think you?

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Who is this Lady?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: O the Dukes Cousin; he came late from travel sir.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Respect belongs to him.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: For as I said Lady,
They are merry that is the worst you can report of them:
They are neither dangerous, nor immodest.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: And there I think I left.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Abuses me.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Now to proceed, Lady; perhaps I swore I loved you,
If you believe me not, you are much the wiser.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: He speaks still in my person, and derides me.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: For I can cog with you.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: You can all do so .
We make no question of men's promptness that way.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: And smile, and; wave a chair with comely grace too,
Play with our Tassel gently, and do fine things,
That catch a Lady sooner than a virtue.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I never used to let man live so long
That wronged me.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Talk of Battalions, woo you in a skirmish:
Divine my mind to you Lady; and being sharp set,
Can court you at half pike: or name your weapon,
We cannot fail you Lady.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Now he dies:
Were all succeeding hopes stored up within him.

sp.speaker: 1 Ge.
sp.l: O fie, in the Court sir?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I most dearly thank you sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Ge.
sp.l: It is rage ill spent upon a passionate mad-man.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: That shall not privilege him forever sir:
A mad-man call you him? I have found too much reason
Sound in his injury to me, to believe him so .

sp.speaker: 1 Ge.
sp.l: If ever truth from man's lips may be held
In reputation with you, give this confidence;
And this his love-fit, which we observe still,
By his flattering and his fineness: at some other time,
He will go as slovenly as heart can wish.
The love and pity that his Highness shows to him,
Makes every man the more respectful of him:
Has never a passion, but is well provided for ,
As this of Love, he is full fed in all;
His swing as I may term it: have but patience,
And ye shall witness somewhat.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Still he mocks me:
Look you, in action, in behaviour sir;
Hold still the chair, with a grand mischief to you,
Or I will set so much strength upon your heart sir ~~

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I feel some power has restrained me Lady:
If it be sent from love, say, I obey it,
And ever keep a voice to welcome it.
Thou Deity, swift winged love,
Sometimes below, sometimes above,
Little in shape, but great in power,
Thou that makest a heart thy Tower,
And thy loop-holes, Ladies eyes,
From whence thou strikest the fond and wise.
Did all the shafts in thy fair quiver
Stick fast in my ambitious liver;
Yet thy power would I adore,
And call upon thee to shoot more.
shoot more, shoot more.
sp.stage: Enter one like a Cupid offring to shoot at him.
sp.l: I prithee hold though, sweet Celestial boy;
I am not requited yet with love enough,
For the first arrow that I have within me:
And if thou be an equal archer Cupid
Shoot this Lady, and twenty more for me.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Me sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: It is nothing but device, fear it not Lady;
You may be as good a maid after that shaft Madam,
As ever your mother was at twelve and a half:
It is like the boy that draws it, it has no sting yet.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: It is like the miserable maid that draws it ~~
That sees no comfort yet, seeing him so passionate.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Strike me the Duchess of Valois in love with me,
With all the speed thou canst, and two of her women.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: You shall have more.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Tell them I tarry for them.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Who would be angry with that walking trouble now
That hurts none but itself?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: I am better quieted.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: I will have all women-kind struck in time for me
After thirteen once:
I see this Cupid will not let me want,
And let him spend his forty shafts an hour,
They shall be all found from the Dukes Exchequer;
He is come already.

div1.stage: Enter againe the same Cupid, two brothers, 6 women Maskers, Cupids bow bent all the way towards them, the first woman singing and playing, A Priest.

sp.l: O turn thy bow,
Thy power we feel and know,
Fair Cupid turn away thy bow:
They be those golden Arrows,
Bring Ladies all their sorrows,
And till there be more truth in men,
Never shoot at maid again.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: What a felicity of whores are here?
And all my concubines, struck bleeding new:
A man can in his life time make but one woman,
But he may make his fifty Queens a month.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Have you remembered a Priest honest brothers?

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Yes sister, and this is the young gentleman,
Make you no question of our faithfulness.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: His growing shame sister provokes our care.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: He must be taken in this fit of love Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: What else sir? he shall it.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: Enough.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Be cheerful wench.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Now by the stroke of pleasure, a deep oath.
Nimbly hopped Ladies all; what height they bear too?
A story higher than your common statures;
A little man must go up stairs to kiss them:
What a great space there is
Betwixt loves dining Chamber, and his Garret?
I will try the utmost height ~~ the Garret stoops methinks;
The rooms are made all bending, I see that ,
And not so high as a man takes them for .

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Now if you will follow me sir, I have that power,
To make them follow you.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Are they all shot?

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: All, all sir, every mothers daughter of them.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Then there is no fear of following; if they be once shot,
They will follow a man to the devil ~~ As for you sir ~~

div1.stage: Ex. with the Lady, & the Maskers.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Me sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Nay sweet sir.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: A noise, a threatening; did you not hear it sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Without regard sir, so would I hear you.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: This must come to something, never talk of that Sir,
You never saw it otherwise.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Nay dear merit ~~

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Me above all men?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Troth you wrong your anger.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: I will be armed my honourable Lecher.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: O fie sweet sir.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: That devours women's honesties by lumps,
And never showest thy pleasure.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: What do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: What does he mean to engross all to himself?
There is others love a whore, as well as he sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: O if that be part of the fury, we have a City
Is very well provided for that case;
Let him alone with her , sir we have women
Are very charitable to proper men,
And to a Soldier that has all his limbs;
Marry the sick and lame gets not a penny:
Right women's charity, and the husbands follow it too:
Here comes his highness sir.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: I will walk to cool myself.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Who is that ?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: The brother of Shamont.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He is Brother then
To all the Courts love, they that love discreetly,
And place their friendliness upon desert:
As for the rest, that with a double face
Look upon merit, much like fortunes visage,
That looks two ways, both to life's calms and storms,
I will so provide for him, chiefly for him,
He shall not wish their loves, nor dread their envies.
And here comes my Shamont .

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: That Ladies virtues are my only joys,
And he to offer to lay siege to them?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Shamont.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Her goodness is my pride; in all discourses,
As often as I hear rash tongued gallants,
Speak rudely of a woman, presently
I give in but her name, and they are all silent:
O who would lose this benefit?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come hither sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: It is like the gift of healing, but diviner;
For that but cures diseases in the body,
This works a cure on fame, on reputation:
The noblest piece of Surgery upon earth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Shamont he minds me not.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: A Brother do it?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Shamont I say.

div1.stage: Gives him a touch with his switch.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Ha?
If he be mortal, by this hand he perishes;
Unless it be a stroke from heaven, he dies for it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why, how now sir? it was I.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: The more is my misery.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why, what is the matter prithee?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Can you ask it sir?
No man else should; stood forty lives before him,
By this I would have oped my way to him;
It could not be you sir, excuse him not,
Whatever he be, as you are dear to honour,
That I may find my peace again.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Forbear I say.
Upon my love to truth, it was none but I.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Still miserable?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come, come, what ails you sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Never sate shame cooling so long upon me,
Without a satisfaction in revenge,
And heaven has made it here a sin to wish it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Hark you sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O have undone me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Cruelly undone me;
I have lost my peace, and reputation by you:
Sir pardon me, I can never love you more.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What language call you this sirs?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Truth my Lord, I have seldom heard a stranger. ~~

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: He is a man of a most curious valour,
Wondrous precise, and punctual in that virtue.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But why to me so punctual? my last thought
Was most entirely fixed on his advancement:
Why, I came now to put him in possession
Of his fair fortunes: what a mis-conceiver it is?
And from a Gentleman of our Chamber merely,
Made him vice-admiral; I was settled in it,
I love him next to health: call him Gentlemen;
Why would not you, or you have taken as much,
And never murmured?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Troth, I think we should my Lord,
And there is a fellow walks about the Court,
Would take a hundred of them.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I hate you all for it,
And rather praise his high pitched fortitude,
Though in extremes for niceness: now I think on it,
I would I had never done it. ~~ Now sir, where is he?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: His suit is only fit to be excused.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He shall not be excused, I love him dearlier:
Say we entreat him; go, he must not leave us .
So virtue bless me, I never knew him paralleled;
Why, he is more precious to me now, than ever.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: With much fair language, we have brought him?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thanks ~~ Where is he?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Yonder sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come forward man.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Pray pardon me, I am ashamed to be seen sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Was ever such a touchy man heard of?
Prithee come nearer.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: More into the light?
Put not such cruelty into your requests my Lord,
First to disgrace me publicly, and then draw me
Into men's eyesight, with the shame yet hot
Upon my reputation.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What disgrace sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: What?
Such as there can be no forgiveness for ,
That I can find in honour.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: That is most strange sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Yet I have searched my bosom to find one,
And wrestled with my inclination,
But it will not be: would you had killed me sir,
With what an ease had I forgiven you then?
But to endure a stroke from any hand
Under a punishing Angels, which is justice,
Honour disclaim that man, for my part chiefly:
Had it been yet the malice of your sword,
Though it had cleft me, it had been noble to me;
You should have found my thanks paid in a smile
If I had fell unworded; but to shame me,
With the correction that your horse should have,
Were you ten thousand times my royal Lord,
I cannot love you never, nor desire to serve you more.
If your drum call me I am vowed to valour,
But peace shall never know me yours again,
Because I have lost mine own, I speak to die sir;
Would you were gracious that way to take off shame,
With the same swiftness as you power it on :
And since it is not in the power of Monarchs
To make a Gentleman, which is a substance
Only begot of merit, they should be careful
Not to destroy the worth of one so rare,
Which neither they can make; nor lost, repair.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You have set a fair light sir before my judgment,
Which burns with wondrous clearness; I acknowledge it,
And your worth with it: but then sir, my love,
My love ~~ what gone again?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: And full of scorn my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: That language will undo the man that keeps it,
Who knows no difference twixt contempt and manhood.
Upon your love to goodness, gentlemen,
Let me not lose him long: how now?

sp.speaker: Hunts.
sp.l: The game is at height my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Confound both, thee and it: hence break it off;
He hates me brings me news of any pleasure:
I felt not such a conflict since I could;
Distinguish betwixt worthiness and blood

div1.stage: Enter the two brothers, 1 Gentleman, with those that were the Maskers, and the Cupid.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: I heartily commend your project Gentlemen,
It was wise and virtuous.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: It was for the safety
Of precious honour sir, which near blood binds us to :
He promised the poor easy fool there marriage,
There was a good maiden-head lost in the belief on it,
Beshrew her hasty confidence.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: O no more sir,
You make her weep again; alas poor Cupid:
Shall she not shift herself?

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: O by no means sir:
We dare not have her seen yet, all the while
She keeps this shape, it is but thought device,
And she may follow him so without suspicion,
To see if she can draw all his wild passions,
To one point only, and that is love, the main point:
So far his highness grants, and gave at first,
Large approbation to the quick conceit,
Which then was quick indeed.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: You make her blush in sooth.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: I fear it is more the flag of shame, than grace sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: They both give but one kind of colour sir:
If it be bashfulness in that kind taken,
It is the same with grace; and there she weeps again.
In truth you are too hard, much, much too bitter sir,
Unless you mean to have her weep her eyes out,
To play a Cupid truly.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Come, have done then:
We should all fear to sin first; for it is certain,
When it is once lodged, though entertained in mirth,
It must be wept out, if it ever come forth.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Now it is so well, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Faithfully welcome sir,
Go Cupid to your charge; he is your own now;
If he want love, none will be blamed but you.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: The strangest marriage, and unfortunatest Bride
That ever human memory contained;
I cannot be myself for it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: How now sir, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: His melancholy passion is half spent already,
Then comes his angry fit at the very tail of it,
Then comes in my pain gentlemen; he has beat me even to a
Cullis. I am nothing, right worshipful, but very pap,
And jelly: I have no bones, my body is all one business,
They talk of ribs, and chines most freely abroad in the world,
Why, I have no such thing; whoever lives to see me dead
Gentlemen, shall find me all mummy good to fill gallipots
And long dildo glasses: I shall not have a bone to throw
At a dog.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Alas poor vassal, how he goes?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O Gentlemen,
I am unjointed, do but think of that :
My breast is beat into my maw, that what I eat,
I am fain to take it in all at mouth with spoons;
A lamentable hearing; and it is well known, my belly
Is driven into my back.
I earned four Crowns a month, most dearly Gentlemen,
And one he must have when the fit is upon him,
The privy purse allows it, and it is thriftiness,
He would break else some forty pounds in casements,
And in five hundred years undo the Kingdom:
I have cast it up to a quarrel.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: There is a fellow kicked about court, I would
He had his place brother, but for one fit of his indignation.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: And suddenly I have thought upon a means for it.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: I Prithee how?

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: It is but preferring Brother
This stock fish to his service, with a letter
Of commendations, the same way he wishes it,
And then you win his heart: for of my knowledge
He has laid wait this half year for a fellow
That will be beaten; and with a safe conscience
We may commend the carriage of this man in it;
Now servants he has kept, lusty tall feeders,
But they have beat him, and turned themselves away:
Now one that would endure, is like to stay,
And get good wages of him; and the service too
Is ten times milder Brother, I would not wish it else.
I see the fellow has a sore crushed body,
And the more need he has to be kicked at ease.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Aye sweet Gentlemen, a kick of ease, send me to such a Master.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: No more I say, we have one for thee, a soft footed Master,
One that wears wool in his toes.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O Gentlemen, soft garments may you wear,
Soft skins may you wed,
But as plump as pillows, both for white and red.
And now will I reveal a secret to you,
Since you provide for my poor flesh so tenderly,
he has hired mere Rogues, out of his Chamber window,
To beat the Soldier, Monsieur Shamonts Brother.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: That nothing concerns us sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: For no cause Gentlemen,
Unless it be for wearing shoulder points,
With longer tags than his.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: Is not that somewhat?
Birlakin sir, the difference of long tags,
Has cost many a man's life, and advanced other some,
Come follow me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: See what a gull am I:
O every man in his profession;
I know a thump now, as judiciously,
As the proudest he that walks, I will except none;
Come to a tag, how short I fall? I am gone.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I have been ruminating with myself,
What honour a man loses by a kick:
Why, what is a kick? the fury of a foot,
Whose indignation commonly is stamped
Upon the hinder quarter of a man;
Which is a place very unfit for honour,
The world will confess so much:
Then what disgrace I pray, does that part suffer
Where honour never comes, I would fain know that ?
This being well forced, and urged, may have the power
To move most Gallants to take kicks in time,
And spurn out the duelloes out of the kingdom,
For they that stand upon their honour most,
When they conceive there is no honour lost,
As by a table that I have invented
For that purpose alone, shall appear plainly,
Which shows the vanity of all blows at large,
And with what ease they may be took of all sides,
Numbering but twice one the Letters Patience
From C. P. to E. I doubt not but in small time
To see a dissolution of all bloodshed,
If the Reformed Kick do but once get up :
For what a lamentable folly it is,
If we observe it, for every little jostle,
Which is but the ninth part of a sound thump,
In our meek computation, we must fight forsooth, yes,
If I kill, I am hanged; if I be killed myself,
I die for it also: is not this trim wisdom?
Now for the Con, a man may be well beaten,
Yet pass away his fourscore years smooth after:
I had a father did it, and to my power
I will not be behind him.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O well met.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Now a fine punch or two, I look for it duly.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I have been to seek you.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Let me know your lodging sir,
I will come to you once a day, and use your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I am made the fittest man for thy Society:
I will live and die with thee: come show me a Chamber;
There is no house but thine, but only thine,
That is fit to cover me: I have took a blow sirra.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I would you had indeed: why, you may see sir;
You will all come to it in time, when my book is out.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Since I did see thee last, I have took a blow.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Pha sir that is nothing; I have took forty since.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: What? and I charged thee thou shouldest not?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Aye sir, you might charge your pleasure,
But they would give it me, whether I would or no.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O I walk without my peace, I have no companion now;
Prithee resolve me, for I cannot ask
A man more beaten to experience,
Than thou art in this kind, what manner of blow
Is held the most disgraceful, or distasteful?
For thou dost only censure them by the hurt,
Not by the shame they do thee: yet having felt
Abuses of all kinds, thou mayst deliver,
Though it be by chance, the most injurious one.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: You put me to it sir; but to tell you truth,
They are all as one with me, little exception.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: That little may do much, let us have it from you.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: With all the speed I may: first then, and foremost,
I hold so reverently of the Bastinado sir,
That if it were the dearest friend in the world,
I would put it into his hand.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Go to, I will pass that then.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: You are the more happy sir,
Would I were past it too:
But being accustomed to it, It is the better carried.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Will you forward?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Then there is your souse, your wherret, and your dowst,
Tugs on the hair, your bob on the lips, a whelp on it,
I never could find much difference: Now your thump,
A thing derived first from your Hemp-beaters,
Takes a man's wind away, most spitefully:
There is nothing that destroys a Colic like it,
For it leaves no wind in the body.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: On sir, on .

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Pray give me leave, I am out of breath with thinking on it.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: This is far off yet.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: For the twinge by the nose,
It is certainly unsightly, so my tables says,
But helps against the head-ache, wondrous strangely.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O your crushed nostrils slakes your opilation
And makes your pent powers flush to wholesome sneezes.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I never thought there had been half that virtue
In a wrung nose before.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O plenitude sir:
Now come we lower, to our modern kick,
Which has been mightily in use of late,
Since our young men drank Coltsfoot: and I grant you,
It is a most scornful wrong, because the foot plays it;
But mark again, how we that take it, requite it
With the like scorn, for we receive it backward;
And can there be a worse disgrace retorted?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And is this all?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: All but a lug by the ear,
Or such a trifle.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Happy sufferer,
All this is nothing to the wrong I bear:
I see the worst disgrace, thou never feltest yet;
It is so far from thee, thou canst not think on it;
Nor dare I let thee know, it is so abject.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I would you would though, that I might prepare for it,
For I shall have it at one time or another:
If it be a thwack, I make account of that ;
There is no new fashioned swap that ever came up yet,
But I have the first of them, I thank them for it.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Hast thou enquired?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: But Can hear nothing Madam.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: If there be but so much substance in thee
To make a shelter for a man disgraced,
Hide my departure from that glorious woman
That comes with all perfection about her :
So noble, that I dare not be seen of her ,
Since shame took hold of me: upon thy life
No mention of me.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I will cut out my tongue first,
Before I will loose my life, there is more belongs to it.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: See there is a Gentleman, enquire of him.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: For Monsieur Shamont Madam?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: For whom else sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Why, this fellow dares not see him.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Shamont Madam?
His very name is worse than a fever to him,
And when he cries, there is nothing stills him sooner;
Madam, your Page of thirteen is too hard for him,
It was tried in the wood-yard.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Alas poor grieved Merit!
What is become of him? if he once fail,
Virtue shall find small friendship: farewell then
To Ladies worths, for any hope in men,
He loved for goodness, not for Wealth, or lust,
After the worlds foul dotage, he never courted
The body but the beauty of the mind,
A thing which common courtship never thinks on :
All his affections were so sweet and fair,
There is no hope for fame if he despair.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Good morrow to you again most heartily sir,
Cry you mercy I heard you not, I was somewhat busy.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: He takes it as familiarly, as an Ave,
Or precious salutation: I was sick till I had one,
Because I am so used to it.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: However you deserve, your friends and; mine, here
Give you large commendations in this Letter,
They say you will endure well.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I would be loath
To prove them liars: I have endured as much
As mortal pen and Ink can set me down for .

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Say you me so ?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I know and feel it so sir,
I have it under black and white already;
I need no pen to paint me out.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: He fits me,
And hits my wishes pat, pat: I was never
In possibility to be better manned,
For he is half lamed already, I see it plain,
But take no notice of it, for fear I make
The Rascal proud, and dear, to advance his wages;
First let me grow into particulars with you;
What have you endured of worth? let me hear.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Marry sir, I am almost beaten blind.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: That is pretty well for a beginning,
But many a mill-horse has endured as much.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Shame on the millers heart for his unkindness then.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Well sir, what then?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I have been twice thrown down stairs, just before supper.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Puh, so have I, that is nothing.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Aye but sir,
Was yours pray before supper?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: There thou possessed me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Aye marry, that is it, it had been less grief to me,
Had I but filled my belly, and then tumbled,
But to be flung down fasting, there is the dolour.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: It would have grieved me, that indeed: proceed sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I have been plucked and; tugged by the hair of the head
About a gallery, half an Acre long.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Yes, that is a good one, I must needs confess,
A principal good one that , an absolute good one,
I have been trod upon , and spurned about,
But never tugged by the hair, I thank my fates.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O it is a spiteful pain.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Peace, never speak of it,
For putting men in mind of it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: To conclude,
I am burst sir: my belly will hold no meat.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: No ? that makes amends for all.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Unless it be puddings,
Or such fast food, any loose thing beguiles me, I am never the better for it.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Shepherds will stay with thee?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes sir, or Cauldrons.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Very well sir:
Any your burst fellows must take heed of surfeits:
Strange things it seems, you have endured;

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Too true sir.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: But now the question is, what you will endure
Hereafter in my service?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: That shall be reason sir, for I am but froth;
Much like a thing new calved, or come more nearer sir,
You have seen a Cluster of Frog-spawns in April
Even such a starch am I, as weak and tender
As a green woman yet.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Now I know this,
I will be very gently angry with thee,
And kick thee carefully.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: O aye sweet sir.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Peace, when thou art offered well, lest I begin now.
Your friends and mine have writ here for your truth,
They will pass their words themselves and I must meet them.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Then have you all:
As for my honesty there is no fear of that ,
For I have never a whole bone about me.

div1.stage: Musick. Enter the passionate Cousen, rudely, and carelesly Apparell'd, unbrac'd, and untrust: The Cupid following.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Think upon love, which makes all creatures handsome,
Seemly for eyesight; go not so diffusedly,
There are great Ladies purpose sir to visit you.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Grand plagues, shut in my casements, that the breaths
Of their Coach-mares reek not into my Nostrils;
Those beasts are but a kind of Bawdy fore-runners.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: It is not well with you,
When you speak ill of fair Ladies.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Fair mischiefs, give me a nest of Owls, and take them;
Happy is he say I, whose window opens
To a brown Bakers chimney, he shall be sure there
To hear the Bird sometimes after twilight:
What a fine thing it is methinks to have our garments
Sit loose upon us thus, thus carelessly,
It is more manly, and more mortifying;
For we are so much the readier for our shrouds:
For how ridiculous were it, to have death come,
And take a fellow pinned up like a Mistress?
About his neck a Ruff, like a pinched Lantern,
Which Schoolboys make in winter; and his doublet
So close and pent; as if he feared one prison
Would not be strong enough, to keep his soul in ;
But his Tailor makes another:
And trust me, for I know it when I loved Cupid
He does endure much pain, for the poor praise
Of a neat sitting suit.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: One may be handsome sir,
And yet not pained, nor proud.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: There you lie Cupid
As bad as Mercurie there is no handsomeness,
But has a wash of Pride and Luxury,
And you go there too Cupid. Away dissembler,
Thou takest the deeds part which befools us all;
Thy Arrow heads shoot out sinners: hence away,
And after thee I will send a powerful charm,
Shall banish thee forever.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Never, never,
I am too sure thine own.
Hence all you vain Delights,
As short as are the nights,
Wherein you spend your folly,
There is naught in this life sweet,
If man were wise to see it,
But only Melancholy,
O sweetest melancholy.
Welcome folded Arms, and fixed eyes,
A sigh that piercing mortifies,
A look that is fastened to the ground,
A tongue chained up without a sound.
Fountain heads, and pathless Groves,
Places which pale passion loves:
Moon-light walks, when all the fowls
Are warmly housed, save Bats and Owls;
A mid-night Bell, a parting groan,
These are the sounds we feed upon ;
Then stretch our bones in a still gloomy valley,
Nothing is so dainty sweet as lovely melancholy.

div1.stage: Enter at another doore Laper, The Cupids Brothers watching his comming.

sp.speaker: 1 Br.
sp.l: So, so , the Woodcock is ginned;
Keep this door fast brother.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: I will warrant this.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: I will go incense him instantly;
I know the way to it.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: Will it not be too soon think you,
And make two fits break into one?

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Pah, no , no ; The tail of his melancholy
Is always the head of his anger, and follows as close,
As the Report follows the powder.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: This is the appointed place, and the hour struck,
If I can get security for his truth,
I will never mind his honesty: poor worm,
I durst lay him by my wife, which is a benefit
Which many masters have not: I shall have no maid
Now got with child, but what I get myself,
And that is no small felicity: In most places
They are got by the men, and put upon the Masters:
Nor shall I be resisted when I strike,
For he can hardly stand; these are great blessings.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: I want my food, deliver me a varlet.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How now: from whence comes that ?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: I am allowed a Carcass to insult on ;
Where is the villain?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: He means not me I hope.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: My maintenance rascals; my Bulk, my exhibition.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Bless us all,
What names are these? would I were gone again.
sp.stage: The passionate man enters in furie, with a Truncheon,
sp.l: A curse upon thee for a slave,
Art thou here, and heardest me rave?
Fly not sparkles from mine eye,
To show my indignation nigh?
Am I not all foam, and fire?
With voice as hoarse, as a Town-crier?
How my back opes and shuts together,
With fury, as old men's with weather?
Couldst thou not hear my teeth gnash hither?
No truly sir, I thought it had been a Squirrel,
Shaving a Hazelnut.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Death, hell, fiends, and darkness,
I will thrash thy mangy carcass.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O sweet sir.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: There cannot be too many Tortures.
Spent upon those lousy Quarters.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Hold, o.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Thy bones shall rue, thy bones shall rue.
Thou nasty, scurvy, mongrel Toad,
Mischief on thee;
Light upon thee,
All the plagues
That can confound thee
Or did ever reign abroad:
Better a thousand lives it cost,
Than have brave Anger spilt or lost.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: May I open mine eyes yet, and safely peep?
I will try a groan first ~~ o ~~ Nay then he is gone.
There was no other policy but to die,
He would have made me else. Ribs are you sore?
I was never beaten to a tune before.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Lapet.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Again?

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Look, look, he is flat again,
And stretched out like a Coarse a handful longer
Than he walks trust me brother. Why Lapet
I hold my life we shall not get him speak now.
Monsieur Lapet it must be a privy token,
If any thing fetch him, he is so far gone.
We come to pass our words for your man's truth.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O gentlemen you are welcome: I have been thrashed in faith.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: How? thrashed sir?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Never was Shrove-tuesday Bird
So cudgeled gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Pray how? by whom sir?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Nay that I know not.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Not who did this wrong?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Only a thing came like a walking song.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: What beaten with a Song?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Never more tightly, gentlemen:
Such crotchets happen now and then, methinks,
He that endures well, of all water's drinks.

div1.stage: Enter Shamonts Brother, the Souldier, and 1. Gent.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Yes yes, this was a Madman, sir, with you,
A passionate Madman.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Who would have looked for this sir?

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: And must be privileged? a pox privilege him:
I was never so dry beaten since I was born,
And by a litter of rogues, mere rogues, the whole twenty
Had not above nine elbows amongst them all too:
And the most part of those left-handed rascals,
The very vomit, Sir, of hospitals,
Bridewells, and Spittle-houses; such nasty smellers,
That if they had been unfurnished of club-truncheons,
They might have cudgeled me with their very stinks,
It was so strong, and sturdy: and shall this,
This filthy injury, be set off with madness?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Nay take your own bloods council sir, hereafter,
I will deal no further in it: if you remember,
It was not come to blows, when I advised you.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: No , but I ever said, it would come to something,
And it is upon me, thank him: were he kin
To all the mighty Emperors upon earth,
He has not now in life three hours to reckon;
I watch but a free time.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Your noble brother, sir, I will leave you now.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Soldier I would I could persuade my thoughts
From thinking thee a brother, as I can
My tongue from naming of it: thou hast no friend here,
But fortune and thy own strength, trust to them.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: How? what is the incitement, sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Treachery to virtue;
Thy treachery, thy faithless circumvention:
Has Honour so few daughters, never fewer,
And must thou aim thy treachery at the best?
The very front of virtue? that blessed Lady? the Dukes sister?
Created more for admiration's cause,
Than for loves ends; whose excellency sparkles
More in divinity, than mortal beauty;
And as much difference betwixt her mind and body,
As betwixt this earths poor centre and the Sun:
And couldst thou be so injurious to fair goodness,
Once to attempt to court her down to frailty?
Or put her but in mind that there is weakness,
Sin, and desire, which she should never hear of?
Wretch, thou hast committed worse than Sacrilege,
In the attempting of it, and oughtest to die for it.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: I rather ought to do my best, to live, sir;
Provoke me not; for I have a wrong sits on me,
That makes me apt for mischief; I shall lose
All respects suddenly of friendship, Brother-hood,
Or any sound that way.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: But beware me most;
For I come with a two-edged injury;
Both my disgrace, and thy apparent falsehood,
Which must be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: I courted her , sir:
Love starve me with delays when I confess it not.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: There is nothing then but death
Can be a penance fit for that confession.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: But far from any vicious taint.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: O sir,
Vice is a mighty stranger grown to courtship.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Nay then the fury of my wrong light on thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Forbear, the Duke is at hand,
Here, hard at hand, upon my reputation.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: I must do something now.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: I will follow you close sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: We must entreat you must not; for the Duke
Desires some conference with you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Let me go,
As you are gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Faith we dare not sir.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Dare ye be false to honour, and yet dare not
Do a man justice? give me leave ~~

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Good sweet sir.
He has sent twice for you.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Is this brave, or manly?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I prithee be conformed.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Death ~~

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Peace, he is come in troth.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: O have you betrayed me to my shame afresh?
How am I bound to loath you?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Shamont welcome,
I sent twice.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: But my Lord, he never heard of it.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Pray pardon him, for his falseness, I did Sir,
Both times; I would rather be found rude than faithless.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I love that bluntness dearly: he has no vice.
But is more manly than some others virtue,
That less it out only for show or profit.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Will it please you quit me sir, I have urgent business?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come, you are so hasty now: I sent for you
To a better end.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: And if it be an end,
Better or worse, I thank your goodness for it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I have ever kept that bounty in condition,
And thankfulness in blood, which well becomes
Both Prince and Subject, that where any wrong
Bears my impression, or the hasty figure
Of my repented anger, I am a Law
Even to myself, and doom myself most strictly
To Justice, and a noble satisfaction:
So that , what you in tenderness of honour,
Conceive to be loss to you, which is nothing
But curious opinion, I will restore again,
Although I give you the best part of Genoa
And take to boot but thanks for your amends.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: O miserable satisfaction,
Ten times more wretched than the wrong itself;
Never was ill better made good with worse:
Shall it be said that my posterity
Shall live the sole heirs of their fathers shame?
And raise their wealth and glory from my stripes?
You have provided nobly bounteous sir,
For my disgrace, to make it live forever,
Out-lasting Brass or Marble:
This is my fears construction, and a deep one,
Which neither argument nor time can alter:
Yet I durst swear, I wrong your goodness in it sir,
And the most fair intent of it, which I reverence
With admiration, that in you a Prince,
Should be so sweet, and temperate a condition,
To offer to restore where you may ruin,
And it with justice, and in me a servant,
So harsh a disposition, that I cannot
Forgive where I should honour, and am bound to it.
But I have ever had that curiosity
In blood, and tenderness of reputation,
Such an antipathy against a blow,
I cannot speak the rest: Good sir discharge me,
It is not fit that I should serve you more,
Nor come so near you; I am made now for privacy,
And a retired condition, that is my suit,
To part from Court forever, my last suit.
And as you profess bounty, grant me that , Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I would deny thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Health reward you, sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He is gone again already, and takes hold
Of any opportunity, not riches
Can purchase him, nor honours, peaceably,
And force were brutish: what a great worth is gone with him,
And but a gentleman? well, for his sake,
I will never offend more those I cannot make:
They were his words, and shall be dear to memory.
Say I desire to see him once again;
Yet stay, he is so well forward of his peace,
It were pity to disturb him: he would groan
Like a soul fetched again; and that were injury,
And I have wronged his degree too much already.
Call forth the gentlemen of our chamber instantly.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: I shall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I may forget again,
And therefore will prevent: The strain of this
Troubles me so , one would not hazard more.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Your will my Lord?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Yes; I discharge you all.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: My Lord ~~

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Your places shall be otherwise disposed of.

sp.speaker: 4 Gent.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Reply not, I dismiss you all:
You are gentlemen, your worths will find you fortunes;
Nor shall your farewell tax me of ingratitude,
I will give you all noble remembrances,
As testimonies against reproach and malice,
That you departed loved.

sp.speaker: 3 Gen.
sp.l: This is most strange, sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: But how is your grace furnished, these dismissed?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Seek me out Grooms.
Men more insensible of reputation,
Less curious and precise in terms of honour,
That if my anger chance let fall a stroke,
As we are all subject to impetuous passions,
Yet it may pass unmurmured, undisputed,
And not with braver fury prosecuted.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: It shall be done, my Lord.

sp.speaker: 3 Gen.
sp.l: Know you the cause sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Not I kind gentlemen, but by conjectures,
And so much shall be yours, when you please.
Thanks sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Gen.
sp.l: We shall in the mean time think our selves guilty
Of some foul fault, through ignorance committed.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: No , it is not that , nor that way.

sp.speaker: 4 Gen.
sp.l: For my part,
I shall be disinherited, I know so much.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Why sir, for what?

sp.speaker: 4 Gen.
sp.l: My sire is of a strange humour,
He will form faults for me, and then swear them mine,
And commonly the first begins with lechery.
He knows his own youths trespass.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Before you go,
I will come and take my leave, and tell you all sirs.

sp.speaker: 3 Gen.
sp.l: Thou wert ever just and kind.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: That is my poor virtue sir,
And parcel valiant; but it is hard to be perfect:
The choosing of these fellows now will puzzle me,
Horribly puzzle me; and there is no judgment
Goes true upon man's out-side, there is the mischief:
He must be touched, and tried, for gold or dross;
There is no other way for it, and that is dangerous too;
But since I am put in trust, I will attempt it:
The Duke shall keep one daring man about him:
Soft, who comes here? a pretty bravery this:
Everyone goes so like a gentleman,
It is hard to find a difference, but by the touch.
I will try your metal sure.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Why what do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Nay, if you understand it not, I do not.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Yes, would you should well know,
I understand it for a box on the ear Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: And on my troth, that is all I gave it for .

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: It were best it be so .

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: This is a brave Coward,
A jolly threatening Coward; he shall be Captain:
Sir, let me meet you an hour hence in the Lobby.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Meet you? the world might laugh at me then in faith.

sp.speaker: 1 Ge.
sp.l: Lay by your scorn and; pride, they are scurvy qualities,
And meet me, or I will hox you while I have you,
And carry you gambrelled thither like a Mutton.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Nay, if you be in earnest, here is my hand
I will not fail you.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: It is for your own good.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Too much for your own good, sir, a pox on you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: I prithee curse me all day long so .

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Hang you.

sp.speaker: Gal:
sp.l: I will make him mad; he is loath to curse too much to me;
Indeed I never yet took box on the ear,
But it redounded, I must needs say so ~~

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Curse, curse, and then I go.
Look how he grins, I have angered him to the kidneys.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Was ever such a prigging coxcomb seen?
One might have beat him dumb now in this humour,
And he would have grind it out still:
O here is one made to my hand,
Methinks looks like a Craven;
Less pains will serve his trial: some slight jostle.

sp.speaker: Pl. f.
sp.l: How? take you that sir:
And if that content you not ~~

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Yes very well sir, I desire no more.

sp.speaker: Pl. f.
sp.l: I think you need not;
For you have not lost by it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Who would have thought this would have proved a gentleman?
I will never trust long chins and little legs again,
I will know them sure for gentlemen hereafter:
A gristle but in show, but gave his cuff
With such a fetch, and reach of gentry,
As if he had had his arms before the flood;
I have took a villainous hard task upon me;
Now I begin to have a feeling of it.
sp.stage: Enter Lapet, and Clowne his servant, and so habited.
sp.l: O here comes a tried piece, now, the reformed kick.
The millions of punches, spurns, and nips
That he has endured? his Buttock is all black Lead,
He is half a Negro back-ward; he was past a Spaniard
In eighty eight, and more Egyptian-like;
His Table and his Book come both out shortly,
And all the Cowards in the Town expect it;
So if I fail of my full number now,
I shall be sure to find them at Church corners,
Where Dives and the suffering Ballads hang.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Well, since thou art of so mild a temper,
Of so meek a spirit, thou mayst live with me,
Till better times do smile on thy deserts.
I am glad I am got home again.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I am happy in your service, sir,
You will keep me from the Hospital.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: So, bring me the last proof, this is corrected.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Aye, you are too full of your correction, sir.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Look I have perfect Books within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Bid him put all the Thumps in Pica Roman,
And with great Tees, (you vermin) as Thumps should be.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Then in what Letter will you have your Kicks?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: All in Italica, your Backward blows
All in Italica, you Hermaphrodite:
When shall I teach you wit?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: O let it alone,
Till you have some yourself sir.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: You mumble?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: The Victuals are locked up ;
I am kept from mumbling.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: He prints my Blows upon pot-paper too, the rogue,
Which had been proper for some drunken Pamphlet.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Monsieur Lapet how the world rings of you sir?
Your name sounds far and near.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: A good report it bears, for an enduring name ~~

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: What luck have you sir?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Why, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I am but thinking on it.
I have heard you wish this five year for a place.
Now there is one fallen, and freely without money too;
And empty yet, and yet you cannot have it.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: No ? what is the reason? I will give money for it,
Rather than go without sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: That is not it, sir;
The troth is, there is no gentleman must have it
Either for love or money: it is decreed so ;
I was heartily sorry when I thought upon you.
Had you not been a gentleman I had fitted you.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Who I a gentleman? a pox I am none, sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How? why did you ever think I was?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: What? not a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I would thou hadst put it upon me in faith.
Did not my Grand-father cry Cony skins?
My father Aquavitæ? a hot gentleman:
All this I speak on in your time and memory too;
Only a rich Uncle died and left me chattels,
You know all this so well too ~~

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Pray excuse me, sir, have not you Arms?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Yes, a poor couple here.
That serve to thrust in wildfowl.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Heralds Arms,
Symbols of gentry, sir: you know my meaning;
They have been shown and seen.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: They have.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: I'fex have they.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Why I confess, at my wives instigation once,
(As women love these Heralds kickshaws naturally)
I bought them: but what are they think you? puffs.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Why, that is proper to your name being Lapet
Which is La fart after the english letter.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: The Herald, sir, had much ado to find it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: And can you blame him?
Why it is the only thing that puzzles the devil.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: At last he looked upon my name again,
And having well compared it, this he gave me,
The two Cholics playing upon a wind instrument.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: An excellent proper one: but I pray tell me,
How does he express the Cholics?
They are hard things.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: The Cholics? with hot trenchers at their bellies,
There is nothing better, Sir, to blaze a Cholic.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: And are not you a gentleman by this sir?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: No , I disclaim it: no belly-ache upon earth
Shall make me one: he shall not think
To put his gripes upon me,
And wring out gentry so , and ten pound first.
If the wind instrument will make my wife one,
Let her enjoy it, for she was a Harpers Grand-child:
But sir, for my particular, I renounce it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Or to be called so ?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Aye sir, or imagined.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: None fitter for the place: give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: A hundred thousand thanks, beside a Bribe sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: You must take heed
Of thinking toward a gentleman, now.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Pish, I am not mad, I warrant you: nay more sir,
If one should twit me in the teeth that I am a gentleman,
Twit me their worst, I am but one since Lammas,
That I can prove, if they would see my heart out.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Marry in any case keep me that evidence.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Here comes my servant, Sir, Galoshio
Has not his name for naught, he will be trod upon :
What says my Printer now?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Here is your last proof Sir.
You shall have perfect Books now in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: These marks are ugly.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: He says, sir, they are proper:
Blows should have marks, or else they are nothing worth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But why a Peel-crow here?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I told them so sir:
A Scar-crow had been better.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How Slave? look you Sir,
Did not I say, this Wherret, and this Bob,
Should be both Pica Roman.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: So said I Sir, both Picked Romans,
And he has made them Welsh Bills,
Indeed I know not what to make of them.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Hey-day; a Souse, Italica?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Yes, that may hold Sir,
Souse is a bonaroba, so is Flops too.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: But why stands Bastinado so far off here?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Alas you must allow him room to lay about him, sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why lies this Spurn lower than that Spurn, sir?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Marry this signifies one kicked down stairs, sir,
The other in a Gallery: I asked him all these questions.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Your Books name?
Prithee Lapet mind me, you never told me yet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Marry but shall sir: it is called The up-rising of the kick,
And the downfall of the Duello.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Bring that to pass you will prove a happy member,
And do your Country service: your young bloods
Will thank you then, when they see fourscore.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I hope
To save my hundred Gentlemen a month by it,
Which will be very good for the private house.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Look you, your Table is finished sir already.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Why then behold my Master-piece: see, see, sir,
Here is all your Blows, and Blow-men whatsoever,
Set in their lively colours, givers, and takers.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Troth wondrous fine, sir.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Nay, but mark the postures,
The standing of the takers I admire more than the givers,
They stand scornfully, most contumeliously, I like not them
O here is one cast into a comely figure.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: My Master means him there that is cast down headlong.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How sweetly does this fellow take his Dowst?
Stoops like a Camel, that Heroic beast,
At a great load of Nut-megs; and how meekly
This other fellow here receives his Wherret?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: O Master here is a fellow stands most gallantly,
Taking his kick in private behind the hangings,
And raising up his hips to it. But o, sir,
How daintily this man lies trampled on ?
Would I were in thy place, whatever thou art :
How lovely he endures it?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: But will not these things, sir, be hard to practise, think you?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O , easy, sir: I will teach them in a Dance.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: How? in a dance?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I will lose my new place else,
Whatever it be; I know not what it is yet.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: And now you put me in mind, I could employ it well,
For your grace, specially: For the Dukes cozen
Is by this time in his violent fit of mirth,
And a devise must be sought out for suddenly,
To over-cloy the passion.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Say no more, sir,
I will fit you with my Scholars, new practitioners,
Endurers of the time.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Whereof I am one sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: You carry it away smooth; give me thy hand, sir.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: Hark, hark, how loud his fit is grown.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 1. Bro.
sp.l: Now let our sister lose no time, but ply it
With all the power she has.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: Her shame grows big, brother;
The Cupids shape will hardly hold it longer,
It would take up half an Ell of China Damask more,
And all too little: it struts perilously:
There is no tampering with these Cupids longer,
The mere conceit with womankind works strong.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: The laugh comes nearer now,
It were good we were not seen yet.

div1.stage: Enter Passion. and Base his Jester.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.
And was he bastinadoed to the life? ha, ha, ha.
I prithee say, Lord General, how did the Rascals
Entrench themselves?

sp.speaker: Base.
sp.l: Most deeply, politically, all in ditches.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: It is thought he will never bear arms in the field again,
Has much ado, to lift them to his head, sir.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: I would he had.

sp.speaker: Base.
sp.l: On either side round Truncheons played so thick,
That Shoulders, Chines, nay Flanks were paid to the quick.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Well said Lord General: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: But pray how grew the difference first betwixt you?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: There was never any sir; there lies the jest man;
Only because he was taller than his brother;
There is all my quarrel to him; and methought
He should be beaten for it, my mind so gave me, sir,
I could not sleep for it; Ha, ha, ha, ha.
Another good jest quickly, while it is hot now;
Let me not laugh in vain: ply me, O ply me,
As you will answer it to my Cozen Duke.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Alas, who has a good jest?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: I fall, I dwindle in it.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Ten Crowns for a good jest: have you a good jest, sir?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: A pretty moral one.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Let us have it, whatever it be.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: There comes a Cupid
Drawn by six fools.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: That is nothing.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Help it, help it then.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I have known six hundred fools drawn by a Cupid.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Aye that , that , that is the smarter Moral: ha, ha, ha.
Now I begin to be Song-ripe methinks.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I will sing you a pleasant air, sir, before you ebb.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: O how my Lungs do tickle? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: O how my Lungs do tickle? o, o, ho, ho.
Set a sharp Jest
Against my breast,
Then how my Lungs do tickle?
As Nightingales,
And things in Cambrick rails,
Sing best against a prickle,
Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Ho, ho, ho, ho, ha.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Laugh.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Laugh.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Laugh.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Laugh.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Wide.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Loud.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: And vary.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: A smile is for a simpering Novice.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: One that never tasted Caviar,

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Nor knows the smack of dear Anchovis.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Ho, ho, ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: A giggling waiting wench for me,
That shows her teeth how white they be.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: A thing not fit for gravity.
For theirs are foul and hardly three.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Democritus thou ancient Fleerer,
Now I miss thy laugh, and have since.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: There you named the famous Geerer,
That ever geared in Rome, or Athens

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: How brave lives he that keeps a fool,
Although the rate be deeper?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: But he that is his own fool sir,
Does live a great deal cheaper.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Sure I shall burst, burst, quite break thou art so witty.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: It is rare to break at Court for that belongs to the City.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Ha, ha, my spleen is almost worn to the last laughter.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: O keep a corner for a friend, a jest may come hereafter.
