div1.stage: Enter Lapet and Clowne, and foure other like fooles, dancing, the Cupid leading, and bearing his Table, and holding it up to Lapet at every strain, and acting the postures.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Twinge all now, twinge, I say.
Souse upon Souse.
Douses single.
Jostle sides.
Knee Belly.
Kicksee Buttock.
Down derry.

div1.stage: Enter Soldier, Shamonts Brother, his sword drawne.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Not angry Law, nor doors of Brass shall keep me
From my wrongs expiation, to thy Bowels,
I return my disgrace; and after turn
My face to any death that can be sentenced.

sp.speaker: Base.
sp.l: Murder, O murder, stop the murderer there ~~

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I am glad he is gone; he has almost trod my guts out;
Follow him who list for me, I will have no hand in it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O it was your luck and mine to be squelched Mister.
Has stamped my very Puddings into Pancakes.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: O Brothers, o, I fear it is mortal: help, O help,
I am made the wretchedest woman, by this accident,
That ever love beguiled.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: We are undone Brother,
Our shames are too apparent: Away receptacle
Of Luxury, and dishonour, most unfortunate,
To make thyself but lucky to thy spoil,
After thy Sexes manner: lift him up Brother;
He breathes not to our comfort, he is too wasted
Ever to cheer us more: A Surgeon speedily;
Hence; the unhappiest that ever stepped aside,
She will be a Mother before she is known a Bride.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Thou hadst a most unfortunate conception,
Whatever thou provest to be; in midst of mirth
Comes ruin, for a welcome, to thy birth.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: This is a beautiful life now; privacy
The sweetness and the benefit of essence:
I see there is no man, but may make his paradise;
And it is nothing, but his love, and dotage
Upon the worlds foul joys, that keeps him out of it:
For he that lives retired in mind, and spirit,
Is still in paradise, and has his innocence,
Partly allowed for his companion too,
As much as stands with justice: here no eyes
Shoot their sharp pointed scorns upon my shame;
They know no terms of reputation here,
No punctual limits, or precise dimensions;
Plain downright honesty is all the beauty
And elegance of life found amongst shepherds;
For knowing nothing nicely, or desiring it,
Quits many a vexation from the mind,
With which our quainter knowledge does abuse us ;
The name of envy is a stranger here,
That dries men's bloods abroad, robs health and rest,
Why here is no such fury thought on : no , nor falsehood,
That brotherly disease, fellow-like devil,
That plays within our bosom, and betrays us .

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: O are you here?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: La Nove it is strange to see thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: I have rid one horse to death,
To find you out, sir.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: I am not to be found of any man
That saw my shame, nor seen long.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Good, your attention:
You ought to be seen now, and found out sir,
If ever you desire before your ending
To perform one good office, nay a dear one,
Man's time can hardly match it.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Be it as precious
As reputation; if it come from Court
I will not hear of it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: You must hear of this, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Must?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: You shall hear it.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: I love thee, that thou wilt die.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: It were nobler in me,
Than in you living: you will live a murderer,
If you deny this office.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Even to death sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Why then you will kill your brother.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Your Brother sir:
Bear witness heaven, this man destroys his brother
When he may save him, his lest breath may save him:
Can there be wilfuller destruction?
He was forced to take a most unmanly wrong,
Above the suffering virtue of a Soldier,
Has killed his Injurer, a work of honour;
For which , unless you save him, he dies speedily
My conscience is discharged, I am but a friend,
A Brother should go forward where I end.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Dies?
Say he be naught, that is nothing to my goodness,
Which ought to shine through use, or else it loses
The glorious name it is known by : he is my brother;
Yet peace is above blood: Let him go; aye,
But where is the nobleness of affection then?
That must be cared for too, or I am imperfect,
The same blood that stood up in wrath against him,
Now in his misery runs all to pity;
I would rather die than speak one syllable
To save myself: but living as I am,
There is no avoiding of it, the worlds humanity
Expects it hourly from me: curse of fortune,
I took my leave so well too: Let him die,
It is but a brother lost; so pleasingly,
And swiftly I came off, it were more than irksomeness,
To tread that path again; and I shall never
Depart so handsomely: But then where is posterity?
The consummation of our house and name?
I am torn in pieces betwixt love and shame.

div1.stage: Enter Lapet, Clown, Poultrot, Moulbazon, and others, the new Court Officers.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Good morrow fellow Poltrot, and Moulbazon,
Good morrow fellows all.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Monsieur Lapet ?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Look, I have remembered you, here is books apiece for you.

sp.speaker: Moul.
sp.l: O sir, we dearly thank you.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: So you may;
There is two impressions gone already sirs.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What no ? in so short a time?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: It is as I tell you sir,
My Kick sells gallantly, I thank my stars.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: So does your Table; you may thank the Moon too.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: It is the Book sells the Table.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: But it is the Book-seller
That has the money for them, I am sure of that.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: It will much enrich the Company of Stationers,
It is thought it will prove a lasting benefit,
Like the Wise Masters, and the Almanacs,
The hundred Novels, and the Book of Cookery,
For they begin already to engross it,
And make it a stock-book, thinking indeed
It will prove too great a benefit, and help,
For one that is new set up : they know their way,
And make him Warden, ere his beard be gray.

sp.speaker: Moul.
sp.l: Is it possible such virtue should lie hid,
And in so little paper?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How? Why there was the Carpenter,
An unknown thing, an odoriferous Pamphlet,
Yet no more Paper, by all computation,
Than Ajax Telamon would use at once,
Your Herring proved the like , able to buy
Another Fishers Folly, and your Pasquill
Went not below the mad-caps of that time,
And shall my elaborate Kick come behind think you?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Yes, it must come behind, it is in Italica too,
According to your humour.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Not in sale, varlet.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: In sale, sir? it shall sail beyond them all I trow.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: What have you there now? o, Page, twenty-one

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: That Page is come to his years, he should be a serving-man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Mark how I snap up the Duello there:
One would not use a dog so ,
I must needs say; but is for the common good.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Nay sir, your Commons seldom fight at sharp,
But buffet in a ware-house.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: This will save
Many a gentleman of good blood from bleeding sirs,
I have a curse from many a Barber Surgeon;
They would give but too much money to call it in ;
Turn to Page forty-five see what you find there.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: O out upon him,
Page forty-five that is an old thief indeed.

div1.stage: Enter Duke, the Lady his sister, 1 Gent.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: The Duke, clap down your Books; away Galoshio

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Indeed I am too foul to be in the presence,
They use to shake me off at the chamber door still.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Good my Lord, grant my suit; let me not rise
Without the comfort of it: I have not often
Been tedious in this kind.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sister, you wrong yourself,
And those great virtues that your fame is made of,
To waste so much breath for a Murderers life.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: You cannot hate the offence more than I do, sir,
Nor the offender, the respect I owe
Unto his absent brother, makes me a suitor,
A most importunate sister; make me worthy
But of this one request.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I am deaf
To any importunacy, and sorry
For your forgetfulness; you never injured
Your worth so much, you ought to be rebuked for it:
Pursue good ways, end as you did begin,
It is half the guilt to speak for such a sin.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: This is loves beggary right, that now is ours ,
When Ladies love, and cannot show their powers.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: La Nove?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Are these our new attendants?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: We are my Lord, and will endure as much
As better men, my Lord, and more I trust.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: My Lord, a decayed Gentleman,
That will do any service.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A decayed one?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: A renounced one indeed; for this place only.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We renounce him then go, discharge him instantly.
He that disclaims his gentry for mere gains,
That man is too base to make a vassal of .

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: What says the Duke?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Faith little to your comfort sir,
You must be a gentleman again.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: There is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Marry, the fates forfend: never while I breath sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: The Duke will have it so , there is no resisting.
He spied it in your fore-head.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: My wife's doing.
She thought she should be put below her betters now,
And sued to have me a gentleman again.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: And very likely sir:
Marry I will give you this comfort when all is done,
You will never pass but for a scurvy one,
That is all the help you have: come show your pace.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: The heaviest gentleman that ever lost place;
Bear witness I am forced to it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Though you have a courser title yet upon you,
Than those that left your places, without blame,
It is in your power to make yourselves the same:
I cannot make you gentlemen, that is a work
Raised from your own deservings; merit, manners,
And in-born virtue does it. Let your own goodness
Make you so great, my power shall make you greater;
And more to encourage you, this I add again,
There is many Grooms now exact Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Methinks it is strange to me to enter here:
Is there in nature such an awful power,
To force me to this place? and make me do this?
Is man's affections stronger than his will ?
His resolution? was I not resolved
Never to see this place more? Do I bear
Within my breast one blood that confounds the other?
The blood of love, and will , and the last weakest?
Had I ten Millions, I would give it all now,
I were but past it, or it would never come;
For I shall never it, or not it well,
But spoil it utterly betwixt two passions.
Yonder is the Duke himself, I will not it now,
Had twenty lives their several sufferings in him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who is that went out now?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I saw none, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nor you?

sp.speaker: Moul.
sp.l: I saw the glimpse of one my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Whatever it was, methought it pleased me strangely,
And suddenly my joy was ready for it.
Did you not mark it better?

sp.speaker: Pol. and; Moul.
sp.l: Troth my Lord,
We gave no great heed to it.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: It will not be answered,
It brings me hither still; by main force hither:
Either I must give over to profess humanity,
Or I must speak for him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It is here again:
No marvel it was so pleasing, it is delight
And worth itself, now it appears unclouded.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: My Lord ~~
He turns away from me: by this hand
I am ill-used of all sides: it is a fault
That fortune ever had to abuse a goodness.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Methought you were saying somewhat.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Mark the Language,
As coy as fate; I see it will never be granted.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We little looked in troth to see you here yet.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Not till the day after my brothers death, I think.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sure some great business drew you.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: No in sooth, sir,
Only to come to see a brother die sir,
That I may learn to go too; and if he deceive me not,
I think he will do well in it of a soldier,
Manly, and honestly: and if he weep then,
I shall not think the worse of his man-hood for it,
Because he is leaving of that part that has it.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Has slain a noble gentleman, think on it, sir?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: I would I could not sir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Our Kinsman too.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: All this is but worse sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: When it is at worst,
Yet seeing thee, he lives.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: My Lord ~~

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He lives,
Believe it as thy bliss, he dies not for it:
Will this make satisfaction for things past?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: O my Lord ~~

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Will it? speak.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: With greater shame to my unworthiness.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Rise then, we are even: I never found it harder
To keep just with a man: my great work is ended.
I knew your brothers pardon was your suit, sir,
However your nice modesty held it back.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: I take a joy now, to confess it, sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: My Lord ~~

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Hear me first, sir, whatever your news be:
Set free the Soldier instantly.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: It is done, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: In effect: it was part of my news too,
There is fair hope of your noble kinsman's life sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: And the most admired change
That living flesh ever had; he is not the man my Lord;
Death cannot be more free from passions, sir,
Than he is at this instant: he is so meek now,
He makes those seem passionate, was never thought of:
And for he fears his moods have oft disturbed you sir,
He is only hasty now for his forgiveness,
And here behold him sir.

div1.stage: Enter Passion, the Cupid, and two brothers.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Let me give thanks first: our worthy Cousin ~~

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Your unworthy trouble sir;
For which , with all acknowledged reverence,
I ask your pardon; and for injury
More known and wilful, I have chose a wife,
Without your counsel, or consent, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A wife? where is she sir?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: This noble Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Whose honour my forgetful times much wronged.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He is madder than he was.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: I would have sworn for him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: The Cupid cousin?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Yes, this worthy Lady, sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Still worse and worse.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Our sister under pardon, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: Which shape Love taught her to assume.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is it truth then?

sp.speaker: 1 Ge.
sp.l: It appears plainly now below the waste my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Shamont, didst ever read of a she-Cupid?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Never in fiction yet: but it might hold sir;
For Desire is of both Genders.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Make that good here:
I take thee at thy word, sir.

div1.stage: He joyns Shamonts hand and his Sisters.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: O my Lord,
Love would appear too bold, and rude from me,
Honour and admiration are her rights,
Her goodness is my Saint, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I see,
You are both too modest to bestow yourselves:
I will save that virtue still; it is but my pains: come,
It shall be so .

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: This gift does but set forth my poverty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, that which you complain of is my riches.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Soldier, now every noise sounds peace, thou art welcome.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Sir my repentance sues for your blessed favour,
Which once obtained, no injury shall lose it;
I will suffer mightier wrongs.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Rise, loved and pardoned;
For where hope failed, nay Art itself resigned,
Thou hast wrought that cure, which skill could never find;
Nor did there cease, but to our peace extend;
Never could wrongs boast of a nobler end.

div1.stage: The Prologue at the reviving of this Play.

sp.l: It is grown in fashion of late in these days,
To come and beg a sufferance to our Plays;
Faith Gentlemen our Poet ever writ
Language so good, mixed with such sprightly wit,
He made the Theatre so sovereign
With his rare Scænes, he scorned this crouching vein:
We stabbed him with keen daggers when we prayed
Him write a Preface to a Play well made.
He could not write these toys; it was easier far,
To bring a Felon to appear at the bar,
So much he hated baseness; which this day,
His Scænes will best convince you of in his Play,
Our Poet bid us say for his own part,
He cannot lay too much forth of his Art :
But fears our over-acting passions may,
As not adorn, deface his laboured Play:
Yet still he is resolute for what is writ
Of Nicer valour, and assumes the wit:
But for the Love-Scænes which he ever meant,
Cupid in his Petticoat should represent,
He will stand no shock of censure; the Play is good,
He says he knows it, if well understood.
But we (blind god) beg, if thou art divine,
Thou wilt shoot thy Arrows round, this Play was thine.
